Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Microrheology of colloidal glasses and gels

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1235955 / 1236242
PI: Furst / Brady

Why and how do colloidal gels form? What is the relationship between gels and glasses, states that occur when particles crowd each other to the point of dynamic arrest? There is long-running debate regarding the mechanism of colloidal gelation, particularly at moderate to high particle volume fractions and relatively weak attractive interactions. The aim of this work is to investigate the microrheology of colloidal glasses and gels to determine whether there is a direct relation between these states. The work is accomplished through the development of optical trapping experiments and Stokesian dynamics simulations that measure the response of individual probe particles in colloidal suspensions. Since theories of colloidal glasses and gels are microrheological, but few studies to date have examined and attempted to validate these theories on microscopic length scales, such work is timely.

Colloidal gels are an arrested, non-equilibrium state of matter that impact shelf life of consumer care products, agrochemicals, coatings, pigments and inks?potentially any product or material in which particles are suspended at high concentration in a fluid phase. Moreover, glasses and gels are ubiquitous states of matter in molecular, macromolecular and colloidal materials. The insights gained under this project have broad implications for our fundamental understanding of many materials. Through an integrated education and professional training of graduate students from underrepresented backgrounds in STEM disciplines and outreach activities involving undergraduate research experiences and research experiences for teachers, this work enhances the capacity for US innovation in the chemical and advanced materials industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Collaborative Research: Microrheology of colloidal glasses and gels

CBET- 1235955

 

Colloidal gels are made up of networks of microscopic particles no larger than 1/100th the width of a human hair. Like the scaffold of a building, this connected structure can hold a gel up against gravity or resist forces that would otherwise cause them to flow. They are found in a wide range of applications—wherever fine particles are suspended in a fluid—and thus are significant to a number of industries, including consumer products, pharmaceuticals, construction materials, high performance coatings, and many more. Despite their importance, the reason gels form and resist flow remain open areas of inquiry and of substantial importance for both fundamental and applied science.

 

Intellectual merit. The project produced several significant advances. With our collaborators, we developed a new model colloidal gel that enables, for the first time, concurrent measurements of the structure, micromechanics, and rheology in the same sample. As part of a collaborative effort, our experiments focused specifically on developing methods to use laser tweezers to measure the interactions between pairs of particles. We used the model system to study the mechanics of “bonds” between particles in a gel network. We can now connect phenomena that occur at the nanoscale through particle-particle interactions to the macroscopic properties of gels—their response to applied stresses. Overall, the work provides a basis for understanding and engineering the stability and flow behavior of colloidal gels and their industrial applications. In a spinoff of the project, we developed a synthesis for mechanically robust, solvent permeable nano-shell particles.­

 

Broader impacts. The project provided training for one PhD student (now employed in industry), experimental resources for a postdoctoral researcher (currently employed in industry) and research experiences for three undergraduates in Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering at the University of Delaware. Two of the undergraduates are employed in industry and one is pursuing a PhD in chemical engineering.
